questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following study designs is the best to prove causation?
questions.explanation:
Randomized controlled trials (RCT) are the strongest and best study design to prove 
causation. They are the gold standard of clinical research. Case-control and cohort studies have a moderate ability to provide evidence for 
causality. Ecological studies or correlational studies are considered as the weakest study design in 
this aspect. The difference between analytical studies and randomised controlled trials is that in the former 
there is no randomisation because it requires the participants to be divided into diseased and 
non-diseased. This can lead to a number of biases that are avoided in RCTs. 117 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: In a clinical trial to evaluate a drug, randomisation was done before starting the trial. What is 
the purpose behind this?

options.a: The two groups will be similar in prognostic factors
options.b: The clinician has no control over the allocation of participants in each group
options.c: The clinician can predict in advance which treatment the subjects will receive
options.d: The sample may be referenced to a known population

questions.explanation:
The main purpose behind randomisation is to eliminate selection bias. In an RCT, participants are randomly assigned to a study group or a control group. It is done only 
after obtaining consent. It removes both known and unknown confounding factors. The heart of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is randomisation. This allows comparability 
between the study and the control population.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is false about randomised control trial?

options.a: Baseline characteristics are similar in both arms
options.b: Investigator’s bias is minimized by double blinding
options.c: The sample size required depends upon the hypothesis
options.d: The dropouts from the trial are not included in the analysis

questions.explanation:
The dropouts from an RCT are included in the final analysis. This type of analysis is called 
intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis. It ignores noncompliance, protocol change, withdrawal, cross-over, and anything that happens 
after randomization during analysis. The exclusion of dropouts may lead to the introduction 
of bias. Note: Per-protocol analysis is a comparison of treatment groups that include only those patients 
who completed the treatment originally allocated to them. Hence, comparability between the 
study and control group is limited and randomisation is lost.

questions.question:
Question 4: A researcher decided to use double-blinding in his trial evaluating two new therapies for 
cystic fibrosis. What is the characteristic feature of this concept?

options.a: Study and control groups are blinded
options.c: Observer and group being observed are blinded
options.d: Group members and analyzer are blinded

questions.explanation:
In double-blind trials, both the group members (study and control group) and the observers are 
not aware of the group allocation.

questions.question:
Question 5: In a clinical trial, what would be the best study design that ensures comparability between 
experimental and control groups?
questions.explanation:
A cross-over study would be the best method to ensure comparability between the experimental 
and control group. In a cross over study design, patients are randomly assigned to the study and control group, and 
then after a period of time, their groups are switched. Here, each patient serves as his/her own 
control which allows for maximum comparability. In a concurrent parallel study design, comparisons are made between two randomly assigned 
groups and there is no switching of groups. This allows only for limited comparability between 
experimental and control groups. Quasi-experiments are studies that aim to evaluate interventions but that do not use 
randomization. The lack of randomisation is the major weakness of quasi trials. The comparability 
in a quasi trial is limited. A per-protocol analysis is a comparison of treatment groups that include only those patients who 
completed the treatment originally allocated. Hence, comparability is limited. 118 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A new drug for multiple sclerosis is undergoing clinical trials where its therapeutic efficacy is 
being confirmed and adverse reactions are being monitored. Which of the following phases is 
the drug most likely in?
questions.explanation:
The confirmation of therapeutic efficacy and monitoring of adverse reactions of a new drug 
happens in phase III of the clinical trial. Purpose of phase III: • Confirmation of the effectiveness of the drug in patients with the target disease • Monitoring of adverse reactions Phase II involves therapeutic exploration which is the evaluation of the efficacy of the drug and 
dose-ranging (determination of the optimum tolerated dose).

questions.question: Question 7: In which of the following phases is the maximum drug failure rate seen?
questions.explanation: Maximum drug failure rates are seen in phase II followed by phase III of a clinical trial.

questions.question:
Question 8: The maximum tolerable dose of a new drug for Alzheimer's disease is to be evaluated. In 
which of the following phases is this done? 113 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The maximum tolerated dose of a new drug is tested in phase I of a clinical trial. Phase I trials are usually performed on healthy volunteers to check the safety and 
pharmacokinetic properties of a drug. The participants in this phase do not gain any direct health 
benefits from taking part. They are generally paid a fee for their time, with the payments being 
regulated and not related to the risk involved.

questions.question:
Question 9: A hypothesis stating that people who continue to smoke are at a higher risk of developing 
lung carcinoma than those who have quit is to be tested. Which of the following study designs 
would you choose for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
To test the given hypothesis that smokers are at a higher risk of developing lung carcinoma than 
those who have quit, the study design chosen is a cessation experiment. The outcomes of termination of a habit or removal of an agent considered to be causally related to 
a disease can be evaluated in a cessation experiment. It is a type of RCT and preventive trial. If the outcome is a significant reduction in disease then 
the association of that habit or agent to the disease is strengthened. A trial of aetiological agents is an experimental epidemiological study to confirm or refute an 
aetiological hypothesis. Clinical trials, for the most part, have been concerned with evaluating therapeutic agents, mainly 
drugs. An uncontrolled trial is an example of a non-randomised trial where there is no control group for 
comparison. 119 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not an example of a randomised controlled trial?
questions.explanation:
Before and after comparison studies are a type of non-randomized trials. These are community trials and centre around comparing the incidence of disease before and after 
the introduction of a preventive measure. They are of two distinct types: • Before and after comparison studies without control. • Before and after comparison studies with control. Non-randomized trials include: • Before and after comparison studies. • Uncontrolled trials. • Natural experiments.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the suspected cause preceding the observed effect an example of?
questions.explanation:
Temporality refers to the condition when the suspected cause precedes the observed effect. It is a 
part of Hill’s criteria for causal association.

questions.question:
Question 12: 114 
Sold by @itachibot While investigating a new disease, you are trying to establish the aetiological agent. Which of 
the following criterion is the most difficult to establish?
questions.explanation:
Specificity is the most difficult criterion to establish in both chronic and acute diseases. This is because a single factor or cause can give rise to more than one disease. Also, most 
diseases are multifactorial in origin with no possibility of demonstrating a one-to-one relationship 
which would indicate specificity.

questions.question: Question 13: What does evidence-based medicine refer to?

options.a: Use of experiments to prove the cause of a disease
options.b: Use of clinical trials to prove safety of drugs
options.c: Use of research findings for taking decisions about patient care
options.d: Use of behavioral modification to prevent disease

questions.explanation:
Evidence-based medicine (EBM) refers to the use of modern research findings to 
guide decision-making about the treatment of individual patients. EBM integrates clinical experience and patient values with the best available research 
information. Research and studies are given high importance in EBM, while opinions and 
conventional wisdom of experts are not taken into consideration in the practice of EBM.

questions.question: Question 14: In the hierarchy of evidence, which of the following rankings is correct?
questions.explanation:
The correct order of ranking of the hierarchy of evidence is: 120 
Sold by @itachibot Meta-analysis and systemic review > Randomised control trial > Cohort study > Case-control study > Case reports.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.explanation:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews. A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular 
question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures. It ranks high in the hierarchy of 
evidence in medicine. Steps of a systematic review: • The research question is formulated. It is always focused. • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established. • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review for quantification but it is not compulsory. questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not a use of epidemiology?
questions.explanation:
Ensuring community participation is not the use of epidemiology. Community participation is a 
principle of primary health care. 121 
Sold by @itachibot Uses of epidemiology: • To study the rise and fall of disease in populations • Community diagnosis • Planning and evaluation • Evaluation of individual’s risks and chances • Syndrome identification • Completing the natural history of disease • Searching for causes and risk factors

questions.question: Question 18: For what purpose were knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) studies first used in India?
questions.explanation:
Knowledge, attitude and practice (KAP) studies were first used in India to study family planning. These studies help in evaluating the knowledge, attitude, and practices of a community. It also 
gives an educational diagnosis.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following quantitative methods is the best to study previous research studies?
questions.explanation:
The quantitative method which is the best to study previous research studies of a selected 
topic/research question is meta-analysis. A systematic review is a process of collecting, reviewing, and presenting information from earlier 
research to answer a question. It is a qualitative technique. It may or may not involve a 
meta-analysis. 122 
Sold by @itachibot Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemiology
